qas.question: How many delegates passed the motion?
How many candidates were sponsored in the 1900 electrion?
What did the 129 delegates do before a debate?
What association was meant to disorganize attempts to support MPs sponsored by trade unions?
What organization had a single leader?

plausible_answers.text: keeping the various strands of opinions in the LRC united

qas.question: What was an easy task for Ramsay MacDonald?

context: After a debate, the <a0_0>129<a0_0/> delegates <b3_0>passed Hardie's motion<b3_0/> to establish "a distinct Labour group in Parliament, who shall have their own whips, and agree upon their policy, which must embrace a readiness to cooperate with any party which for the time being may be engaged in promoting legislation in the direct interests of labour." This created an association called the <b4_0><b5_0>Labour Representation Committee<b5_0/><b4_0/> (LRC), meant to coordinate attempts to support MPs sponsored by trade unions and represent the working-class population. It had no single leader, and in the absence of one, the Independent Labour Party nominee <a1_0>Ramsay MacDonald<a1_0/> was elected as Secretary. He had the difficult task of <b7_0>keeping the various strands of opinions in the LRC united<b7_0/>. The October 1900 "Khaki election" came too soon for the new party to campaign effectively; total expenses for the election only came to £33. Only <a2_0>15<a2_0/> candidatures were sponsored, but two were successful; <b6_0>Keir Hardie<b6_0/> in Merthyr Tydfil and Richard Bell in Derby.
